Thank you, that is exactly the answer I was looking for.

--- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> First, it is important to=
 note that the way networks are activated is not part of the NEAT algorithm=
.  It just evolves the network structure; you can activate that structure h=
owever you want.
> 
> In practice, most NEAT implementations follow the pro=
cedure in the NEAT Software FAQ at http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.htm=
l under question "How are networks with arbitrary topologies activated?"
> =

> To quote from that answer:
> 
> "The activation function, bool Network::=
activate(), gives the specifics. The implementation is of course considerab=
ly different than for a simple layered feedforward network.  Each node adds=
 up the activation from all incoming nodes from the previous timestep. (The=
 function also handles a special "time delayed" connection, but that is not=
 used by the current version of NEAT in any experiments that we have publis=
hed.) Another way to understand it is to realize that activation does not t=
ravel all the way from the input layer to the output layer in a single time=
step. In a single timestep, activation only travels from one neuron to the =
next. So it takes several timesteps for activation to get from the inputs t=
o the outputs. If you think about it, this is the way it works in a real br=
ain, where it takes time for a signal hitting your eyes to get to the corte=
x because it travels over several neural connections. "
> 
> So basically t=
he activation routine does not make any distinction between feedforward or =
recurrent connection:  On each timestep, activations travels the length of =
one connection from every node.  Whether the connection points backwards or=
 forwards doesn't matter.  This approach thus is somewhat easy to program.
=
> 
> However, there is some controversy on whether this approach is always =
best (in terms of computational efficiency) and there are alternatives for =
arbitrary-topology networks.  This issue has been discussed on this group i=
n the past.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "snapmedown" <snapme=
down@> wrote:
> >
> > I mean resolve as in actually getting from inputs to =
outputs.  I don't know what method NEAT and the NEAT family of algorithms u=
ses.
> >
>
